Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Which vessel continues as the popliteal artery after passing through the adductor hiatus?
The profunda femoris artery mainly supplies which region of the lower limb?
Which vessel accompanies the saphenous nerve within the adductor canal?
The dorsalis pedis artery is a direct continuation of which artery?
Union of the anterior and posterior tibial veins forms which vein?
Which artery pierces the interosseous membrane to enter the anterior compartment of the leg?
The small saphenous vein most commonly drains into which vessel?
In the femoral sheath, which structure occupies the intermediate compartment?
Concerning the dorsalis pedis artery, choose the correct answer.
options: It is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery.
It enters the sole of the foot between the two heads of the second dorsal interosseous muscle.
It can be palpated on the dorsum of the foot between the tendons of tibialis anterior and extensor hallucis brevis muscles.
It joins the medial plantar artery.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: The peroneal artery is a branch of which artery?
In the adult, the chief arterial supply of the head of the femur is from:
options: Branches from medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: The plantar arterial arch is formed by the lateral plantar artery and:
Regarding the arteries of the lower limb, mark the correct answer:
options: Pulsation can be readily felt from the medial plantar artery.
The femoral artery gives the lateral genicular branch.
The middle genicular artery is a branch of the femoral artery.
The head of the femur is supplied by the artery accompanying the ligamentum teres of the hip joint.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: The places where the arterial pulsation in the lower limb could be felt include:
options: Femoral artery just below and lateral to the pubic tubercle.
Popliteal artery when the knee joint is fully flexed.
Posterior tibial artery below and behind the lateral malleolus.
Dorsalis pedis artery on the dorsum of the foot.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Regarding arteries of lower limb, choose the correct answer:
options: Profunda femoris artery gives four genicular branches.
Posterior tibial artery enters the sole behind the lateral malleolus.
Dorsalis pedis artery is continuation of anterior tibial artery on the dorsum of the foot.
Plantar arch is mainly formed by the medial plantar artery.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Regarding the veins of the lower limb, the following statement is correct:
options: The great saphenous vein passes behind the medial malleolus.
The small saphenous vein passes in front of the lateral malleolus.
Perforating veins connect the great and small saphenous veins.
Perforating veins have valves directing blood flow from superficial to deep veins.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Regarding veins of lower limb, the following statement is correct:
options: The small saphenous vein drains into the great saphenous vein.
The femoral vein lies lateral to the femoral artery at the base of the femoral triangle.
The great saphenous vein pierces the cribriform fascia to enter the femoral vein.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Regarding femoral artery, mark the correct statement:
options: It lies medial to the femoral vein.
Its uppermost part is enclosed within the femoral sheath.
It enters the thigh at the midpoint of the inguinal ligament.
It passes behind the adductor longus in the adductor canal.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Regarding popliteal artery:
options: It begins at the opening in the adductor canal.
It ends at the lower border of the adductor longus muscle.
Its pulsation can be felt while the knee is extended.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Regarding great saphenous vein, the following statements are true:
options: It starts at the dorsal venous arch.
It passes behind the medial malleolus.
It empties into the femoral vein.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Regarding the popliteal artery, select the correct statement:
options: It lies superficial to the popliteal vein.
It is crossed anteriorly by the tibial nerve.
It terminates by dividing into anterior and posterior tibial arteries.
It ends at the upper border of the popliteus muscle.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Regarding the veins of the lower limb, choose the correct answer:
options: Venae comitantes accompany the popliteal and femoral arteries.
The long saphenous vein ascends behind the medial malleolus.
Drainage of blood from deep veins is helped by contraction of calf muscles and arterial pulsation.
The perforating veins possess valves which direct the blood flow from the deep to superficial veins.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: Regarding the popliteal artery, choose one correct statement:
options: It ends at the level of the medial epicondyle of the femur.
It is deeper than the popliteal vein.
It gives no articular branch in the popliteal fossa.
It accompanies the lateral popliteal nerve in the popliteal fossa.

Vessels of Lower Limb.questionText: The most usual site for feeling pulsations of dorsalis pedis artery is:
The femoral artery enters the thigh at:
The posterior tibial artery passes behind:
Which artery supplies the plantar surface of the foot:
The dorsalis pedis artery is a continuation of:

Heart.questionText: Which of the following structures does NOT form the anterior surface of the heart?
All of the following statements regarding the conducting system of the heart are true EXCEPT:
options: The impulse for cardiac contraction spontaneously begins in the sinoatrial node
The atrioventricular bundle is the sole pathway for conduction of the waves of contraction between the atria and the ventricles
The sinoatrial node is frequently supplied by the right and left coronary arteries
The sympathetic nerves to the heart slow the rate of discharge from the sinoatrial node
The atrioventricular bundle descends behind the septal cusp of the tricuspid valve

Heart.questionText: Which of the following statements concerning the blood supply of the heart is INCORRECT?
options: The coronary arteries are branches of the ascending aorta
The right coronary artery supplies both the right atrium and right ventricle
The circumflex branch of the left coronary artery descends in the anterior interventricular groove and passes around the apex of the heart
Arrhythmias (abnormal heart beats) can occur after occlusion of a coronary artery
Coronary arteries can be classified as functional end arteries

Heart.questionText: The conducting system of the heart is composed of the following structures EXCEPT:
The following anatomic facts regarding the right coronary artery are true EXCEPT:
options: It gives rise to a marginal branch
It passes forward between the right auricle and the pulmonary trunk
It gives rise to an anterior interventricular branch
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It descends in the right atrioventricular groove

Heart.questionText: In patients with tetralogy of Fallot, which of the following cardiac anomalies is characteristic of the condition?
options: Pulmonary stenosis with hypertrophy of the right ventricle
High blood pressure in the left ventricle

Heart.questionText: Pain arising in the heart is commonly referred to the following skin areas EXCEPT:
options: Up into the neck and jaw
Down the medial side of the arm

Heart.questionText: The conducting system of the heart comprises:
options: The sinoatrial node, His bundle, right and left branches
The sinoatrial node, atrioventricular node, His and Her bundle, superior and inferior crura
The atrioventricular node and atrial nodes, His bundle, right and left crura
The sinoatrial node, the atrioventricular node and bundle, right and left branches, and Purkinje fibers network
SA and AV node, His and Her bundle, anterior and inferior crura, Purkinje fibers and network

Heart.questionText: The base of the heart is formed by the:
Which of the following statements is TRUE about the coronary arteries and their branches?
options: The coronary sinus receives blood from the anterior cardiac veins and returns it to the heart
Normally, the posterior interventricular artery comes from the right coronary artery
The anterior ventricular artery is usually a branch of the right coronary artery
The coronary arteries branch off the coronary sinus
The characteristic sounds heard during auscultation of the heart result from blood flowing through the cardiac veins and coronary arteries

Heart.questionText: Which one of the following statements about the pericardium is FALSE?
options: The pericardium has a fibrous, inelastic outer layer
The pericardium has a parietal and visceral layer that secretes fluid
The coronary vessels are found in the visceral pericardium (epicardium)
The pericardial reflections are where the pericardium is fused to the diaphragm
The roots of the great vessels are surrounded by fibrous pericardium

Heart.questionText: Which statement about the coronary arteries is FALSE?
options: The posterior interventricular artery is often a branch of the right coronary artery, but it may branch from the left coronary artery in some individuals
The heart normally has two coronary arteries that emerge from the descending aorta
The heart occupies less than 1/2% of body weight but it uses 4% of the blood pumped to the body

Heart.questionText: Which statement about the cardiac veins is TRUE?
options: The middle cardiac vein runs with the marginal branch of the right coronary artery
Blood from the anterior cardiac veins returns directly to the right atrium without passing through the coronary sinus
The great cardiac vein is found in the anterior atrioventricular sulcus
The coronary sinus is on the anterior surface of the heart
All Thebesian veins empty into the right atrium

Heart.questionText: Which statement about the chambers of the heart is TRUE?
options: The moderator band (septomarginal trabecula) is found in the left ventricle
The fossa ovalis is seen in the right atrium
The mitral (bicuspid) valve is seen in the right ventricle
The semilunar valves are seen in the left and right atria
The pectinate muscles are seen in the left and right ventricles

Heart.questionText: Which of the following is FALSE about the heart's innervation?
options: Sympathetic nerve impulses dilate the coronary arteries and increase the force of contraction of cardiac muscle
Visceral sensory fibers traveling with the sympathetic nerves carry sensation from the heart muscle
Sympathetic innervation to the heart originates in regions T5-T12 of the spinal cord
The phrenic nerve passes close to the heart but does not innervate cardiac muscle
Parasympathetic innervation in the cardiac plexus comes from the vagus nerve

Heart.questionText: The coronary sinus is found in the:
Which of the following statements is TRUE about cardiac innervation?
options: Somatic sensory fibers are supplied to the pericardium by the phrenic nerves
The cardiac plexus of nerves contains only preganglionic sympathetic nerves
The vagus nerve supplies postganglionic sympathetic branches to the heart
The sympathetic nerves to the heart slow down the heart rate
The parasympathetic nerves to the heart speed up the heart rate

Vessels of Thorax.questionText: In a posteroanterior radiograph of the thorax, which of the following structures does NOT form the left margin of the heart shadow?
The arch of the aorta is crossed by:
Azygos vein receives the following veins EXCEPT:
Which of the following pathways is correct for the passage of arterial blood from the heart to the 4th anterior intercostal artery?
options: Axillary artery -> thoracoacromial trunk -> anterior intercostal artery
Subclavian artery -> superior epigastric artery -> anterior intercostal artery
Brachiocephalic trunk -> common carotid artery -> internal thoracic artery -> anterior intercostal artery
Subclavian artery -> internal thoracic artery -> anterior intercostal artery
Subclavian artery -> axillary artery -> internal thoracic artery -> anterior intercostal artery

Vessels of Thorax.questionText: The internal thoracic artery gives the following branches EXCEPT:
Which of the following is TRUE of the azygos vein?
options: It lies close to the intercostal veins but does not connect directly with them
It lies on the left side of the thorax
It is normally part of the portal system of venous drainage
It empties into the superior vena cava
It is typically smaller than the hemiazygos vein

Vessels of Thorax.questionText: Which of the following is FALSE of the circulation of the thoracic wall?
options: Blood supply to the upper anterior thoracic wall comes from the thoracoacromial artery
Blood from the anteriormost aspect of the thoracic wall drains into the internal thoracic vein
Unlike the intercostal arteries, posterior intercostal veins do not anastomose with the anterior intercostal veins
The posterior intercostal arteries are branches of the descending aorta
The internal thoracic artery branches into the musculophrenic and the superior epigastric as it approaches the diaphragm

Vessels of Thorax.questionText: Where is the groove for the subclavian artery located?
options: At the angle of the 1st rib

Vessels of Thorax.questionText: Which of the following statements correctly apply to the internal thoracic artery?
options: It runs posterior to the transversus thoracis muscle.
It ends in the 6th intercostal space.
It divides into the superior and inferior epigastric arteries.
It runs posterior to the superior six ribs.
It gives rise to the posterior intercostal arteries.

Vessels of Thorax.questionText: The azygos vein receives blood from which of the following?
The hemiazygos vein does NOT receive blood from which of the following?
The accessory hemiazygos vein parallels the vertebral column along which vertebral levels?
The musculophrenic arteries give rise to which of the following?
options: Anterior intercostal arteries for intercostal spaces 7-9
Posterior intercostals arteries for intercostal spaces 3-11

Vessels of Thorax.questionText: Anterior and posterior intercostal arteries pass between which two layers?
options: Innermost intercostal muscles and transversalis fascia

Vessels of Thorax.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a branch of the aorta in the thorax?

Heart MCQ Set 2.questionText: All of the following statements correctly apply to the right atrium EXCEPT
options: It receives blood from the superior and inferior vena cava and coronary sinus.
It forms the right side of the heart.
It contains the limbus fossae ovalis.

Heart MCQ Set 2.questionText: The interventricular septum contains which of the following structures?
All of the following statements correctly apply to the right coronary artery EXCEPT
options: Typically supplies the SA node in approximately 60% of people.
Typically supplies the AV node in approximately 80% of people.
Arises from the arch of the aorta.

Heart MCQ Set 2.questionText: Which of the following structures carry highly oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart?
All of the following statements concerning the pericardium are correct EXCEPT
options: The external layer of the sac is fibrous.
The internal layer is reflected onto the heart as the visceral serous layer (epicardium).
The internal layer of the fibrous sac is the parietal serous layer.
The pericardial cavity is the potential space between the parietal and visceral serous layers.
The fibrous pericardium is attached to the sternum by the pericardiacophrenic ligament.

Heart MCQ Set 2.questionText: All of the following veins drain into the coronary sinus EXCEPT
options: oblique vein of the left atrium

Heart MCQ Set 2.questionText: All of the following statements concerning the sinoatrial node are correct EXCEPT
options: It is located near the superior end of the sulcus terminalis.
It is located at the junction of the superior vena cava and the right atrium.
It is known as the pacemaker of the heart.
It is specialized cardiac muscle fiber.

Heart MCQ Set 2.questionText: Which of the following structures is located in the left ventricle?
Which of the following structures is located in the left atrium?
Which of the following statements correctly applies to the tricuspid valve?
options: It guards the left atrioventricular orifice.
It is also known as the mitral valve.
Chordae tendineae attach to the free edges of the cusps.
The apex of each cusp attaches to the fibrous ring around the orifice.

Heart MCQ Set 2.questionText: The pulmonary plexus contains which of the following?
options: cell bodies of visceral afferent fibers
cell bodies of postsynaptic sympathetic fibers
cell bodies of postsynaptic parasympathetic fibers
somatic efferent fibers passing on to diaphragm

Heart MCQ Set 2.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a branch of the right coronary artery?
Which of the following is a result of sympathetic stimulation in the heart?
options: decrease in the rate and strength of contraction
inhibition of the effect of parasympathetic system on coronary arteries, allowing them to dilate
opening and closing of mitral valve

Heart MCQ Set 2.questionText: Sympathetic fibers of the heart are accompanied by visceral afferent fibers that convey which type of sensation?
